item.title: Veterans: Napoleonic Wars Is a New Single-Player Historical RTS Coming to Steam
item.content:encoded:
If you're hankering for a new tactical RTS that will give you a meaty intellectual challenge to chew on, then look no further than developer and publisher Tactical Boar's Veterans: Napoleonic Wars, which is coming to PC sometime soon.

In a press release, Tactical Boar says you'll be "mastering formations, maintaining morale, and making tactical decisions across recreated battlefields" in its game, all while taking command of "historical armies".

You'll need to pay attention to unit experience and morale as you play, as well as common 1790s battlefield formations like the line, the column, and the square. As you progress through campaigns, your units will gain veterancy, giving you greater control over shaping and customizing your armies.

As "increasingly complex tactical scenarios" play out, Veterans: Napoleonic Wars will throw new challenges at you, including the use of artillery, which Tactical Board says "emphasizes the importance of troop maneuvering" as well as "reinforcing the importance of positioning and timing" in battle.

Despite this strategic depth, the studio says Veterans: Napoleonic Wars will offer "accessible, fast-paced gameplay", so if you're not a real-time strategy genius, then you should still find something to enjoy here.

Unlike many other RTS games, this one won't offer any multiplayer features, either; Tactical Boar says the game will be "a focused single-player experience", so don't expect to be taking on your friends here anytime soon.

You can check out the debut trailer for Veterans: Napoleonic Wars, which should be red meat for you if you're a Total War fan (and you're disappointed with more recent releases), right here.

There is, admittedly, not a ton of information in said trailer, but Veterans: Napoleonic Wars doesn't have a release date yet, so that's probably fair enough. If you want to keep up with this one's progress, you can wishlist it on Steam here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Hitman: World of Assassination Cross-Progression Coming in February
item.content:encoded:
You'll soon be able to take advantage of cross-progression in IO Interactive's Hitman: World of Assassination, allowing you to carry on where you left off on other devices, the developer and publisher has announced.

In a news post on its website, IO says cross-progression for the trilogy is coming on February 3rd, and that it won't matter which platform you're playing on, since none of them are exempt from the feature.

As a result of introducing this new feature, however, IO says that the Hitman 2 to Hitman 3 data carryover system introduced back in 2021 needs to be closed, so if you've yet to take advantage of that (should you wish to), now's the time to do so.

Although features like overall game progress, experience, and player level will carry over, along with story progress, there are some things that won't be shared between platforms.

If you've bought Hitman: World of Assassination DLC on one platform, for instance, that doesn't entitle you to that DLC on another platform, and features like in-mission save games, game licenses, and leaderboard scores won't carry over either.

On the subject of save games, IO says that any saves created across connected accounts prior to cross-progression activation will be temporarily disabled, and you'll need to turn the feature off to access them again.

If it's all sounding rather confusing, you can check out the official Hitman: World of Assassination cross-progression FAQ right here. Perhaps that will help to clear up any lingering questions you might have.

If you're wondering what Hitman: World of Assassination is, it's a collection that amalgamates the first, second, and third games in IO Interactive's World of Assassination trilogy of Hitman games.

Despite its definitive nature, IO has stated that Hitman: World of Assassination isn't the end of the series, and that a new game will definitely be happening at some point in the future, although the studio is committed to the upcoming 007 First Light for now.

You can check out Hitman: World of Assassination right now on PC, PlayStation, Xbox, and Switch 2. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Ball x Pit Regal Update Brings New Characters and More Next Week
item.content:encoded:
If you thought you'd completely rinsed October's excellent Ball x Pit, think again. The game is getting a brand new content drop next week in the form of the Regal Update, and it'll bring new characters, new balls, and more.

As revealed in a Steam news post, the Ball x Pit Regal Update launches on January 26th, and its main addition to the game comes in the form of two new treasure seekers: the Carouser and the Falconer.

The Carouser's thrown balls will orbit around him when they return, while the Falconer will be flanked by two falcons who will aid her in throwing balls towards her enemies. They should add a fun new tactical dimension to Ball x Pit.

Developer Kenny Sun is also promising eight new balls as part of the Regal Update, as well as new passive abilities and "some new features many [players] have been crying out for since launch".

He's also teasing a "nice surprise" that he and his fellow Ball x Pit devs "don't want to spoil just yet". I suppose we'll find out what that surprise is when the update arrives next week.

If you're not familiar with Ball x Pit, it's a roguelite that takes inspiration from the likes of Vampire Survivors for its gameplay, as well as arcade classics like Breakout (and, arguably, Space Invaders).

Each level sees you hurling balls at columns of enemies, and since this is effectively a bullet heaven game, you can apply all kinds of absurd modifiers to your balls (ahem), including flame, poison, and bleed effects, plus more.

The game has done very well for itself since launching in mid-October, racking up 300,000 sales within its first week. That number is likely to be higher by now, too.

You can check out Ball x Pit right now on PC, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch and Switch 2, and you can read my review here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Original Granblue Fantasy: Versus to Lose Ranked Matches in April
item.content:encoded:
Granblue Fantasy: Versus will have some of its key online features shut down in April, developer Cygames has announced, although you'll still be able to play the game online with others if you wish.

As announced in a news post on the game's official website, Granblue Fantasy: Versus' online ranked matches will no longer be available starting from April 20th (yes, that's 4/20).

Similarly, online lobbies and rankings will disappear on that date as well, and you'll no longer be able to upload or download match replays either. Not only that, but you won't be able to edit your player profile, and "all banners and text will display as though the game were in Maintenance Mode" for announcements.

As a result of these features being disabled, there are also a number of trophies you won't be able to unlock in the game after April. There are only three, but it'll still stop you from obtaining the Platinum, unfortunately. Here they are.

  • Now the Real Fight Begins! (Complete tutorial matches)
  • Hot Enough for You? (Win an online match)
  • Platinum Sky (As the name suggests, the platinum trophy)

If you've already got the two trophies before the platinum in that list unlocked, then you'll still be able to get the Platinum Sky trophy, but otherwise, you'll have to look elsewhere for your platinum.

Happily, Granblue Fantasy: Versus' sequel, Granblue Fantasy Versus: Rising, isn't going anywhere, and it's "still receiving support with both in-game updates and offline events", as Cygames says. You may be better off migrating there for your anime battling needs.

Things are looking up for the Granblue franchise elsewhere; back in July last year, it was revealed that action RPG spinoff Granblue Fantasy: Relink had managed to hit two million sales worldwide, putting it roughly in line with games like Atlus' Persona 3 Reload.

You can still pick up the original Granblue Fantasy: Versus right now on PC and PlayStation 4 should you wish to, and you can check out our review of the game here.
